title: H01-1042

sentences.text: The purpose of this research is to test the efficacy of applying automated evaluation techniques , originally devised for the evaluation of human language learners , to the output of machine translation -LRB- MT -RRB- systems .
We believe that these evaluation techniques will provide information about both the human language learning process , the translation process and the development of machine translation systems .
This , the first experiment in a series of experiments , looks at the intelligibility of MT output .
A language learning experiment showed that assessors can differentiate native from non-native language essays in less than 100 words .
Even more illuminating was the factors on which the assessors made their decisions .
We tested this to see if similar criteria could be elicited from duplicating the experiment using machine translation output .
Subjects were given a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text .
Some of the extracts were expert human translations , others were machine translation outputs .
The subjects were given three minutes per extract to determine whether they believed the sample output to be an expert human translation or a machine translation .
Additionally , they were asked to mark the word at which they made this decision .
The results of this experiment , along with a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process will be presented here .

Entity-this_research.label: this research
Entity-this_research.description: This research aims to evaluate the effectiveness of automated assessment methods, designed for human language learners, in analyzing the intelligibility of outputs from machine translation systems.

Entity-the_result_of_this_experiment.label: the results of this experiment
Entity-the_result_of_this_experiment.description: The results of this experiment refer to the findings obtained from assessing the intelligibility of machine translation outputs compared to expert human translations, as well as the preliminary analysis of the decision-making factors involved in this evaluation process.

Entity-machine_translation_-lrb-_mt_-rrb.label: machine translation -LRB- MT -RRB- systems
Entity-machine_translation_-lrb-_mt_-rrb.description: Machine translation (MT) systems are automated software applications designed to convert text or speech from one language to another without human intervention.

Entity-the_sample_output.label: the sample output
Entity-the_sample_output.description: The sample output refers to a specific extract of machine translation text presented to subjects in an experiment to assess their ability to distinguish between expert human translations and machine translations.

Entity-extract.label: extracts
aliases: a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text
Entity-extract.description: The term 'extracts' refers to a set of up to six samples of translated newswire text used in an experiment to evaluate the intelligibility of machine translation outputs compared to expert human translations.

mentions.local_name: a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text

Entity-the_intelligibility_of_mt_output.label: the intelligibility of MT output
Entity-the_intelligibility_of_mt_output.description: The intelligibility of MT output refers to the clarity and comprehensibility of text produced by machine translation systems, as assessed by human evaluators in comparison to expert human translations.

Entity-the_first_experiment_in_a_series_.label: the first experiment in a series of experiments
aliases: the first experiment in a series of experiments
Entity-the_first_experiment_in_a_series_.description: The first experiment in a series of experiments focuses on evaluating the intelligibility of machine translation output by comparing it to expert human translations.

mentions.local_name: the first experiment in a series of experiments

Entity-three_minute_per_extract.label: three minutes per extract
Entity-three_minute_per_extract.description: The term 'three minutes per extract' refers to the allocated time given to subjects in an experiment to evaluate and determine whether a sample of translated text is an expert human translation or a machine translation.

Entity-decision.label: decisions
Entity-decision.description: The term 'decisions' refers to the judgments made by assessors regarding whether a given text extract is an expert human translation or a machine translation output, based on specific criteria during the evaluation process.

Entity-the_factor_on_which_the_assessor_.label: the factors on which the assessors made their decisions
aliases: the factors on which the assessors made their decisions
factors on which the assessors made their decisions
Entity-the_factor_on_which_the_assessor_.description: The factors on which the assessors made their decisions refer to the criteria and considerations that evaluators used to distinguish between expert human translations and machine translation outputs during the assessment of intelligibility in translated texts.

mentions.local_name: the factors on which the assessors made their decisions
factors on which the assessors made their decisions

Entity-automated_evaluation_technique.label: automated evaluation techniques
Entity-automated_evaluation_technique.description: Automated evaluation techniques are systematic methods used to assess and measure the quality or performance of outputs, such as language learning or machine translation, through automated processes.

Entity-assessor.label: assessors
Entity-assessor.description: Assessors are individuals who evaluate and differentiate between native and non-native language essays based on specific criteria in a language learning experiment.

Entity-a_preliminary_analysis_of_the_fac.label: a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process
aliases: a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process
Entity-a_preliminary_analysis_of_the_fac.description: A preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process refers to an initial examination of the criteria and considerations that influence how assessors differentiate between expert human translations and machine translation outputs in the context of evaluating intelligibility.

mentions.local_name: a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process

Entity-this_decision.label: this decision
Entity-this_decision.description: This decision refers to the point at which subjects determined whether a sample of translated text was an expert human translation or a machine translation during the evaluation of machine translation output.

Entity-non-native_language_essay.label: non-native language essays
Entity-non-native_language_essay.description: Non-native language essays are written works produced by individuals who are not native speakers of the language in which the essays are written, often used for language assessment and evaluation of language proficiency.

Entity-factor.label: factors
Entity-factor.description: The term 'factors' refers to the specific criteria or elements that assessors considered when making decisions about the intelligibility of machine translation outputs compared to expert human translations.

Entity-mt_output.label: MT output
Entity-mt_output.description: MT output refers to the text produced by a machine translation system as a result of converting source language content into target language content.

Entity-native_from_non-native_language_e.label: native from non-native language essays
Entity-native_from_non-native_language_e.description: The term 'native from non-native language essays' refers to written compositions that are produced by individuals whose first language is the target language (native) compared to those whose first language is different from the target language (non-native), highlighting the differences in language proficiency and writing quality.

Entity-similar_criterion.label: similar criteria
Entity-similar_criterion.description: The term 'similar criteria' refers to the evaluative standards or factors used by assessors to differentiate between expert human translations and machine translation outputs in a study aimed at assessing the intelligibility of machine translation.

Entity-a_machine_translation.label: a machine translation
Entity-a_machine_translation.description: A machine translation refers to the automated process of translating text or speech from one language to another using computer algorithms and software, as opposed to human translators.

Entity-language_learning_experiment.label: language learning experiment
Entity-language_learning_experiment.description: A language learning experiment is a structured research study designed to investigate the processes, methods, and outcomes associated with acquiring a new language.

Entity-machine_translation.label: machine translation
Entity-machine_translation.description: Machine translation refers to the automated process of translating text or speech from one language to another using computer algorithms and software.

Entity-the_development_of_machine_transl.label: the development of machine translation systems
aliases: the development of machine translation systems
Entity-the_development_of_machine_transl.description: The development of machine translation systems refers to the process of creating and improving automated systems that translate text or speech from one language to another, focusing on enhancing their accuracy, efficiency, and overall effectiveness in producing intelligible translations.

mentions.local_name: the development of machine translation systems

Entity-they.label: they
Entity-they.description: The term 'they' refers to the subjects participating in the experiment who were tasked with evaluating the intelligibility of machine translation outputs.

Entity-subject.label: Subjects
Entity-subject.description: Subjects refers to the participants in the study who were tasked with evaluating extracts of translated newswire text to determine whether they were produced by expert human translators or machine translation systems.

Entity-translation_process.label: translation process
Entity-translation_process.description: The translation process refers to the method of converting text or speech from one language to another, which is analyzed in the context of evaluating both human and machine translation outputs.

Entity-the_word.label: the word
Entity-the_word.description: In this context, 'the word' refers to a specific point in the translated text where subjects indicated their decision regarding whether the output was a human translation or a machine translation.

Entity-translated_newswire_text.label: translated newswire text
Entity-translated_newswire_text.description: Translated newswire text refers to excerpts of news articles that have been converted from one language to another, used in the context of evaluating the intelligibility and quality of machine translation outputs compared to expert human translations.

Entity-expert_human_translation.label: expert human translations
Entity-expert_human_translation.description: Expert human translations refer to translations of text that are performed by skilled human translators, ensuring high accuracy and cultural relevance compared to automated translations.

Entity-human_language_learner.label: human language learners
Entity-human_language_learner.description: human language learners are individuals who acquire language skills through various methods and experiences, typically involving the understanding and use of spoken or written language.

Entity-human_language_learning_process.label: human language learning process
Entity-human_language_learning_process.description: The human language learning process refers to the cognitive and developmental mechanisms through which individuals acquire and develop the ability to understand and use language.

Entity-evaluation_technique.label: evaluation techniques
Entity-evaluation_technique.description: Evaluation techniques are systematic methods or tools used to assess, measure, and analyze the effectiveness or quality of processes, systems, or outcomes in various fields.

Entity-intelligibility.label: intelligibility
Entity-intelligibility.description: Intelligibility refers to the clarity and comprehensibility of speech or text, often measured to assess how easily a listener can understand spoken or written language.

Entity-decision_making_process.label: decision making process
Entity-decision_making_process.description: The decision making process refers to the cognitive and psychological activities involved in evaluating options and making choices based on available information and personal or contextual factors.

Entity-preliminary_analysis.label: preliminary analysis
Entity-preliminary_analysis.description: A preliminary analysis is an initial examination or assessment of data or factors that provides insights or informs further investigation in a research context.

Entity-experiment.label: experiment
Entity-experiment.description: An experiment is a systematic and controlled procedure conducted to investigate hypotheses, test theories, or demonstrate known facts within a scientific context.

Entity-research.label: research
Entity-research.description: Research refers to a systematic investigation or study aimed at discovering and interpreting knowledge, often conducted in an academic or scientific context.

summary: The purpose of this research is to test the efficacy of applying automated evaluation techniques , originally devised for the evaluation of human language learners , to the output of machine translation -LRB- MT -RRB- systems . We believe that these evaluation techniques will provide information about both the human language learning process , the translation process and the development of machine translation systems . This , the first experiment in a series of experiments , looks at the intelligibility of MT output . A language learning experiment showed that assessors can differentiate native from non-native language essays in less than 100 words . Even more illuminating was the factors on which the assessors made their decisions . We tested this to see if similar criteria could be elicited from duplicating the experiment using machine translation output . Subjects were given a set of up to six extracts of translated newswire text . Some of the extracts were expert human translations , others were machine translation outputs . The subjects were given three minutes per extract to determine whether they believed the sample output to be an expert human translation or a machine translation . Additionally , they were asked to mark the word at which they made this decision . The results of this experiment , along with a preliminary analysis of the factors involved in the decision making process will be presented here .

Predicate-tests_the_efficacy_of_applying.label: tests the efficacy of applying
Predicate-tests_the_efficacy_of_applying.description: The predicate 'tests the efficacy of applying' indicates an evaluative action performed by the subject, where the subject seeks to determine the effectiveness or success of implementing a specific method, technique, or approach represented by the object. This involves assessing whether the application of the object yields the desired outcomes or benefits in a given context.

Predicate-originally_devised_for_the_eva.label: originally devised for the evaluation of
Predicate-originally_devised_for_the_eva.description: The predicate 'originally devised for the evaluation of' indicates that the subject was specifically created or designed with the primary purpose of assessing or measuring the performance, capabilities, or characteristics of the object. This implies a foundational intent behind the subject's development, suggesting that its functionalities or methodologies are tailored to effectively analyze or evaluate the specified object.

Predicate-applied_to_the_output_of.label: applied to the output of
Predicate-applied_to_the_output_of.description: The predicate 'applied to the output of' indicates a relationship where the subject is utilized or implemented in relation to the results or products generated by the object. It signifies that the subject acts upon, evaluates, or processes the output produced by the object, thereby establishing a functional connection between the two entities.

Predicate-provide_information_about.label: provide information about
Predicate-provide_information_about.description: The predicate 'provide information about' establishes a relationship where the subject conveys knowledge, data, or insights regarding the object. It indicates that the subject serves as a source or medium through which details concerning the object are communicated, enhancing understanding or awareness of the object in question.

Predicate-looks_at.label: looks at
Predicate-looks_at.description: The predicate 'looks at' indicates a relationship where the subject is examining, analyzing, or focusing on the object. It suggests an active engagement with the object, implying that the subject is seeking to understand, evaluate, or gain insights regarding the object in question.

Predicate-showed_that.label: showed that
Predicate-showed_that.description: The predicate 'showed that' indicates a demonstration or presentation of evidence or findings from the subject to the object. It implies that the subject provides information or results that support or clarify the existence, characteristics, or conclusions about the object.

Predicate-can_differentiate.label: can differentiate
Predicate-can_differentiate.description: The predicate 'can differentiate' indicates the ability of the subject to recognize, distinguish, or identify differences between two or more entities or concepts represented by the object. It implies a cognitive process where the subject applies knowledge or criteria to discern variations, classifications, or characteristics that set the entities apart.

Predicate-on_which.label: on which
Predicate-on_which.description: The predicate 'on which' indicates a relationship of dependence or relevance between the subject and the object, suggesting that the subject serves as a basis, criterion, or reference point for the actions, judgments, or evaluations performed by the object.

Predicate-made.label: made
Predicate-made.description: The predicate 'made' indicates an action performed by the subject that results in the creation, formulation, or execution of the object. It implies a transformation or production process where the subject actively contributes to bringing the object into existence or completing it.

Predicate-elicits.label: elicits
Predicate-elicits.description: The predicate 'elicits' indicates that the subject is capable of drawing out, provoking, or generating a response, reaction, or specific information from the object. It suggests an active process where the subject influences or stimulates the object to produce a particular outcome or set of characteristics.

Predicate-is_used_in.label: is used in
Predicate-is_used_in.description: The predicate 'is used in' establishes a functional relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject serves a purpose or plays a role within the context or framework defined by the object. It implies that the subject is actively employed or applied in the scenario described by the object, suggesting a practical or operational connection.

Predicate-were_given.label: were given
Predicate-were_given.description: The predicate 'were given' indicates a transfer of possession or provision, where the subjects are the recipients of something, and the objects are the items or entities that are being provided or assigned to them. This construction implies that the subjects received the objects as a result of an action or decision, highlighting a relationship of giving or allocation.

Predicate-consists_of.label: consists of
Predicate-consists_of.description: The predicate 'consists of' indicates that the subject is made up of, or is composed of, the elements or components represented by the object. It establishes a relationship of composition, where the subject is understood to be a whole that includes the object as a part or constituent.

Predicate-determine_whether_they_believe.label: determine whether they believed
Predicate-determine_whether_they_believe.description: The predicate 'determine whether they believed' serves to assess the belief or conviction of the subjects regarding a particular idea, statement, or situation. It connects the subjects, who are the individuals or entities whose beliefs are being evaluated, with the object, which represents the outcome or conclusion drawn from this evaluation. Essentially, this predicate implies a process of inquiry or analysis aimed at establishing the presence or absence of belief among the subjects.

Predicate-to_be.label: to be
Predicate-to_be.description: The predicate 'to be' serves as a linking verb that establishes an identity or state of existence between the subject and the object. It indicates that the subject is equivalent to or characterized by the object, thereby providing a relationship that defines or describes the subject in terms of the object.

Predicate-will_be_presented.label: will be presented
Predicate-will_be_presented.description: The predicate 'will be presented' indicates a future action where the subject is the entity that is going to be showcased or revealed, and the object is the content or information that will be shared or displayed. This construction implies a formal or structured communication of the object to an audience, suggesting that the subject serves as a basis for the forthcoming presentation of the object.

Predicate-supports.label: supports
Predicate-supports.description: The predicate 'supports' indicates a relationship in which the subject provides assistance, validation, or reinforcement to the object. It implies that the subject contributes positively to the understanding, acceptance, or effectiveness of the object, suggesting a foundational or corroborative role.

Predicate-evaluates.label: evaluates
Predicate-evaluates.description: The predicate 'evaluates' signifies an assessment or analysis performed by the subject on the object, indicating that the subject is determining the quality, effectiveness, or performance of the object in a systematic manner.

Predicate-assess.label: assess
Predicate-assess.description: The predicate 'assess' indicates an evaluative action performed by the subject on the object, where the subject examines, analyzes, or judges the qualities, performance, or outcomes of the object in order to form a conclusion or make a decision.

skos:broader.label: has a broader term
skos:broader.description: The predicate 'has a broader term' establishes a hierarchical relationship between the subject and the object, indicating that the subject is a specific instance or subset that falls under the more general category represented by the object. This relationship implies that the object encompasses a wider scope or a more inclusive concept than the subject.
